Devon Energy Corporation
Bridgeport Gas Plant
Executive Summary

Devon Gas Services owner and operator of the Bridgeport Gas Plant, has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes.  Devon's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However, if a release does occur, facility trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release. 

Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

Basis for Plant

The primary reasons the plants exist are to condition the gas to make marketable. The inlet gas produced in the field is categorized two ways; rich and lean. The "lean" gas, which is typically 1050 BTU or less, can be marketed as long as it is dry. This can be accomplished by glycol dehydration at the field. The "rich" however is higher in BTU content which means it has heavy hydrocarbon liquids that need extracted to meet market specification. The inlet gas at the Bridgeport Plant is approximately 1170 BTU so processing is required. 

Prior to removal of the heavy hydrocarbon liquids the plants perform other gas conditioning tasks. They remove any free water and condensate through front end separation; remove CO2 through amine treating, and glycol and mole sieve dehydration to dry gas.

Bridgeport Plant

The Bridgeport Plant is designed to process 790 MMscf/d of raw natural gas as well as a blended bypass of 100 MMscf/d for a total throughput capacity of 890 MMcf/d. Currently, the Bridgeport plant is averaging approximately 680-700 MMscf/d of gas and 50,000 - 60,000 Bbls/d of product.  The processing of the natural gas is made possible through seven Cryogenic trains. 
1)	- #1 Plant 170 MMSCF/D
2)	- #2 Plant 15 MMSCF/D
3)	- #3 Plant 15 MMSCF/D
4)	- #4 Plant 1

20 MMSCF/D
5)	- #5 Plant 130 MMSCF/D
6)	- #6 Plant 200 MMSCF/D
7)	 -#7 Plant 140 MMSCF/D

Once the raw inlet gas exits the front end liquid separation equipment, CO2 is removed by four inlet amine treaters.
1)	- #2 Unit - 140 gpm - 90 MMSCF/D
2)	- #4 Unit - 550 gpm - 200 MMSCF/D
3)	- #5 Unit - 550 gpm - 250 MMSCF/D
4)	 -#7 Unit - 800 gpm - 310 MMSCF/D

A fourth amine treater is utilized for the liquid pipeline to further remove CO2 from the y-grade product going to Chevron.
	      1) - #1 Unit - 60 gpm 

After CO2 treating the inlet gas is dehydrated at each individual plant prior to entering the cold sections. This is accomplished with 3 molecular sieve beds at each plant #1, #2 and  #3, #4, #5, #6 and #7, two in dehy and one in regen.  The #1 plant utilizes a 12 gpm glycol unit in series with 6 molecular sieve beds. 

The dehydrated raw natural gas then enters the cold sections of the cryogenic plants. Through a process of cross exchange and running through an expander the cryogenic temperatures allow the heavier components to be extracted as a liquid. As a result the raw natural gas is converted into a residue gas stream and a y-grade liquid (ethane plus).


AMINE UNITS COMPLEXITY

All of the amine treaters with the exception of the #1 and #2 amine treaters are used to treat multiple plants. The #4 unit treats gas for the #1 plant, #4 plant and the #6 plant. The #5 unit treats gas for the #5 plant, #2 & #3 plants and a portion of the #6 plant. The #1 amine unit treats liquid product while the #2 amine units treats 80mmcf of the inlet gas for the #1 plant. #7 unit treats gas for plant 7 and an MOC is in place to allow for treatment of plant #1. With the combining of multiple plants being treated by single amine treater serious issues arise when you lose the treater. Treaters are occasionally lost to power failure or mechanical failure. When a Treater is lost a series of drastic and complex decisions must be made very quickly in order to preven

t CO2 freeze up in the demethanizer tower. It is critical that the tower temperatures and pressures be brought up immediately. Failure to do could result in a total plant shut down within minutes. The knowledge and expertise it takes to accomplish this and keep all the plants on is substantial. But just as important as the Treaters are so are the plants themselves as well as the Horsepower it takes to move the gas thru the plants. Any loss of a plant or horsepower requires numerous changes to be made to prevent a Domino effect caused by high or low pressures that will shut down engines or even an inlet valve to a plant. The knowledge required to operate the multiple plants at Bridgeport is highly respected and takes years to acquire. 

RTO  UNITS

After the removal of the CO2 from the gas stream the acid gas must be disposed of. We accomplish this thru the use of (2) Regenerative Thermal Oxidizers. This equipment uses entrained methane in the acid gas to help fuel the incineration process of the CO2. 

This unit requires diligent attention; any shut down of this equipment requires immediate action. All releases of acid gas to the atmosphere must be recorded. If release is over 10lbs of Benzene it must be reported to TCEQ within 48 hrs. 

T.O. UNITS

The Thermal Oxidizer units at the Bridgeport Plant are backup for the RTO units. These units must be put online anytime the RTO goes down. Acid gas is a reportable release and we have minimal time to get the T.O. unit on before we have to report a release. Quick response to this unit is essential.

GLYCOL  UNITS

The Bridgeport Plant has two glycol units. One treats inlet gas for the #1 plant the other treats by-pass gas going around the plant. Both units are critical to the operation of the plants. Any maintenance or shut-down of these units will require major operational changes to be made. These units are also monitored very closely by plant operations personnel. 

STABILIZER  UNIT

The Bridgeport Pl

ant also utilizes a stabilizer unit to condition and stabilize the condensate that comes in from the field as well as the condensate that is brought in on truck. Some of which is third party. The condensate is filtered and heat treated to remove some of the lighter hydrocarbons then is stored for truck sales or pumped to Enterprise Pipeline.

INJECTION  WELLS

The Bridgeport Plant has two injection wells that are also maintained by plant operations personnel. They monitor well head pressure, casing pressure, and booster pump pressure as well as change filters. The injection well is run 24hrs a day to dispose of the saltwater that comes in with the inlet gas. The injection well system requires a lot of time by the plant operator.  

LOADING  RACK

The loading rack at the Bridgeport Plant is used to load finished product, such as Propane, Butane, ISO Butane, Gasoline, etc. The Product is loaded onto 18 wheel truck trailers for transportation to various locations. Two operators as well as contract employees assist in this operation. Loading schedules from marketing keep the product moving and keep our loaders busy.

CRUDE  RACK

The Bridgeport Plant has also installed a Crude Oil unloading rack. Operators and contractors unload 18 wheel truck trailers bringing in crude oil to be off-loaded onto train cars. Marketing has been able to utilize our facility to increase our liquid handling abilities. At times this does increase the work load on our operators to the point that it is hard to keep up. Even with the increased work load our operators have received the Pinnacle award for Rail safety for the last four years in a row.  

RAIL  RACK

In addition to the load rack and the crude rack Bridgeport also has a Rail rack that is used to ship our product to various locations. Our loaders inspect the cars, fill out extensive paperwork and make all the connections required to load the rail cars. The cars have to be moved in and out as needed as well as set in pl

chanical integrity of the process.

Maintenance personnel receive training on (1) an overview of the process, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) applicable maintenance procedures, (4) emergency response plans, and (5) applicable safe work practices to help ensure that they can perform their jobs in a safe manner.  Job plans/written procedures help ensure that work is performed in a consistent manner and provide a basis for training.  Inspections and tests are performed to help ensure that equipment functions as intended and to verify that equipment is within acceptable limits (e.g., adequate wall thickness for pressure vessels).  If a deficiency is identified, employees will correct the deficiency before placing the equipment back into service (if possible), or a management of change team will review the use of the equipment and determine what actions are necessary to ensure the safe operation of the equipment.

Another integral part of the mechanical integrity program is quality assurance.  The Bridgeport Gas Plant incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs.  This helps ensure that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made.

Safe Work Practices

Devon Gas Services has long-standing safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety.  Examples of these include, (1) control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel, (2) a lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, (3) a procedure for safe removal of hazardous substances before process piping or equipment is opened, (4) a permit and procedure to control spark-producing activities (i.e., hot work) and (5) a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space.  These procedures (and others), along with training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that o

ace on one of four different lanes. The cars are then loaded on a schedule to be ready for shipping at next switch.

FRACTIONATION

The Bridgeport Plant has full Fractionation which is controlled by individual Towers. Thru a process of temperature, pressure and refrigeration the natural gas liquids can be separated.  The Y-grade product which is removed from the inlet gas stream at each plant is accumulated in the product surge and is then pumped to fractionation for further refinement or to Chevron Pipeline & Oneok Pipeline. We currently pipeline approximately 47,570 bbl/d including ethane from deethanizer to Chevron & Oneok, and produce approximately 7,600 bbl/d of finished products (Propane, Butane, Iso-Butane, and Natural Gasoline) through fractionation.  

TANK FARM

The tank farm at the Bridgeport Plant is used to store the finished product before sales. These tanks are manually gauged twice a day for accuracy. The plant operators also manually switch each tank as it is made up. We keep up inventory in case we need to pipeline some of the product to maintain adequate room. Monitoring these levels is critical to plant operations. Finished product storage capacity is approximately 1.8 million gallons with the largest being propane and natural gasoline. Inventory is tracked, and reported through plant reports and historian data base. Reports utilized are the "Fractionated Products Log" that operations manage, the "Production Daily Report Summary" which monitors balance, and "Bridgeport Daily Numbers" sent to marketing. This data is pulled directly from meters, operator entries, and manual inputs. Truck and Rail tickets are tallied and entered into the Production Daily Report Summary 

BY-PASS SYSTEM

Two of the Caterpillar 3606 units can be configured to by-pass 70mmcf of gas around the plant. The #4 or #5 KVGR can also be used to by-pass up to 40mmcf for a total of 110mmcf. This blended bypass stream has its own glycol unit to dehydrate the raw gas p

rior to entering sales. These systems can be used to help control inlet gas pressure when other units are down for maintenance or repairs.


SUPPORT SYSTEMS

Other key support systems and equipment utilized for natural gas processing are: Honey Well DCS /FSC Control System, Generation (11 - 3516 Cat Engines driving 750 KW Generator packages), Hot Oil System, Refrigeration System (Clarks & Fricks), Liquid Handling, Loading Facilities, and Utilities (Purchase Power, Air, and Water-Cooling Towers).
 

General Accident Release Prevention and Program Information

The following is a summary of the accident prevention program in place for the process at the facility. Because the processes at the Bridgeport Gas Plant that are regulated by the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) risk management program (RMP) regulation are also subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA's) process safety management (PSM) standard, this summary addresses each of the OSHA PSM elements and describes the management system in place to implement the accident prevention program.

Employee Participation

Devon Gas Services encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention.  Examples of employee participation range from updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information to participating as a member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team.  Employees have access to all information created as part of the facility accident prevention program.  Specific ways that employees can be involved in the accident prevention program are documented in an employee participation plan that is maintained at the facility.

Process Safety Information

Devon Gas Services keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes.  These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventori

es, and equipment design basis/configuration information.  The referenced documents are maintained on file at the facility to provide open access.

Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in material safety data sheets (MSDSs).  This information is supplemented by documents that specifically address known corrosion concerns and any known hazards associated with the inadvertent mixing of chemicals.  For the process, the facility has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters (e.g., temperature, level, composition) in key process parameter documents.  The facility ensures that the process is maintained within these limits using process controls and monitoring instruments, highly trained personnel, and protective instrument systems (e.g., automated shutdown systems).

The Bridgeport Gas Plant also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment.  This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, and electrical rating of equipment.  This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

Devon Gas Services has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the process are identified and controlled.  Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.  

Devon Gas Services primarily used the hazard and operability (HAZOP) analysis technique to perform this evaluation.  HAZOP analysis is recognized as one of the most systematic and thorough hazard evaluation techniqu

es.  The analyses are conducted using a team of people who have operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise.  This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and the team makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary.

The PHA team findings are forwarded to local and corporate management for resolution per Devon's Risk Management Protocol.  Implementation of mitigation options in response to PHA findings is based on a relative risk ranking assigned by the PHA team.  This ranking helps ensure that potential accident scenarios assigned the highest risk receive immediate attention.  All approved mitigation options in response to PHA team findings are tracked until they are completed.  The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained.

To help ensure that the process controls and/or process hazards do not eventually deviate significantly from the original design safety features, the Bridgeport Gas Plant periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results.  These periodic reviews are conducted when major changes occur at the facility, or at minimum every five years.  The results and findings from these updates are documented and retained.  Once again, the team findings are forwarded to management for consideration, and the final resolution of the findings is documented and retained.  

Operating Procedures

Bridgeport Gas Plant maintains written procedures that address various modes of operations, such as (1) unit startup, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, (5) normal shutdown, and (6) initial startup of a new process.  These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators.  These procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current and accu

rate.  The procedures are kept current and accurate by revising them as necessary to reflect changes made through the management of change process.

In addition, the Bridgeport Gas Plant maintains key process parameter documents that provide guidance on how to respond to upper or lower limit exceedence for specific process or equipment parameters.  This information, along with written operating procedures, is readily available to operators in the process unit and for other personnel to use as necessary to safely perform their job tasks.

Training

To complement the written procedures for process operations, the Bridgeport Gas Plant has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process.  New employees receive basic training in facility operations if they are not already familiar with such operations.  After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks.  After operators demonstrate (e.g., through tests, skills demonstration) having adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they can work independently.  In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level.  This refresher training is conducted on an as needed basis or at minimum every three years.  All of this training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify that the operator understood the training.

Contractors

The Bridgeport Gas Plant uses contractors to supplement its workforce during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities.  Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the plant has procedures in place to ensure that contractors (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their wo

rkplace, (4) understand what they should do in event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site safety rules, and (6) inform facility personnel of any hazards that they find during their work.  This is accomplished by providing contractors with (1) a process overview, (2) information about safety and health hazards, (3) emergency response plan requirements, and (4) safe work practices prior to their beginning work.  In addition, Devon Energy has a program in place to evaluate contractor safety programs and performance. Facility personnel periodically monitor contractor performance to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations.

Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs)

Devon Gas Services conducts a PSSR for any new facility or facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information.  The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service.  This review provides one additional check to make sure construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready.  The PSSR team uses checklists to verify all aspects of readiness.  A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves as a quality assurance function by requiring that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.

Mechanical Integrity

Devon Gas Services has well-established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition.  The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures.  In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the me

perations and maintenance activities are performed safely.

Management of Change

Devon Gas Services has a comprehensive system to manage changes to all covered processes.  This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented.  Changes are reviewed to (1) ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and to (2) verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change.  Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures, are updated to incorporate these changes.  In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provided any necessary training on the change.  

Incident Investigation

Devon Gas Services promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury.  The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts, and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident.  The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to facility management for resolution.  Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees (including contractors) who could be affected by the findings.  Incident investigation reports are retained for at least five years so that the reports can be reviewed during PHAs and PHA revalidations.

Compliance Audits

To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, Devon Gas Services periodically

conducts an audit to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented.  Compliance audits are conducted on a periodic basis, at minimum every three years.  Both hourly and staff personnel participate as audit team members.  The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to facility management for resolution.  Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.  


Chemical - Specific Prevention Steps

The processes at the Bridgeport Gas Plant have hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation.  The following is a description of existing safety features applicable to the prevention of accidental releases of regulated substances in the facility.  

Universal Prevention Activities

The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to all RMP-covered processes at the Bridgeport Gas Plant.  Collectively, these prevention program activities prevent or mitigate potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors.


Specialized Safety Features

The Bridgeport Gas Plant has safety features on many units to help (1) contain/control a release, (2) quickly detect a release, and (3) reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release.  The following types of safety features are used in the covered process:

Release Detection

1.	Tanks are gauged
2.	Tanks/vessels are equipped with level and pressure sensors
3.	Hydrocarbon detectors with alarms and shutdowns
4.	High/Low alarms and shutdowns
5.	Plant is staffed 24-hours a day, 7-days a week

Release Containment/Control

1.	Berms around atmospheric tanks
2.	Process relief valves venting vapors to the atmosphere to prevent vessels from rupturing
3.	Process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate

episodic releases
4.	Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual and automated)
5.	Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high temperature, high pressure)
6.	Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system)

Release Mitigation

1.	Trained emergency response personnel
2.	Personal protective equipment (e.g., chemical protective clothing)
3.	SPCC Plan
4.	Fire extinguishers
5.	Emergency planning and drills


Emergency Response Program Information

The Bridgeport Gas Plant maintains a written emergency response program, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment.  The program consists of procedures for responding to the release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released.  The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post incident cleanup and decontamination requirements.  In addition, the facility has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment.  Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties.  The emergency response program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to facility processes.  The emergency response program changes are administered through the Management of Change (MOC) process, which includes informing and/or training affected personnel in the changes. Periodic drills or tabletop exercises are conducted to test the response plan.

The overall emergency response program for the Bridgeport Gas Plant is coor

dinated with the Wise County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). The Hon. Bill McElhaney is the contact for the LEPC (940/627-5743).  This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives.  The Bridgeport Gas Plant has around-the-clock communications capability.  Devon Gas Services operators are automatically called in the event of a process upset.  The operator will then call the appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department).  This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.  In addition to periodic LEPC meetings, Devon Gas Services conducts periodic emergency drills that involve emergency response organizations, and the Bridgeport Gas Plant provides annual refresher training to local emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated substances in the facility.  

Five - Year Accident History

According to Devon personnel, there have been no chemical release incidents resulting in an injury or off-site impact in the last (5) years at the Bridgeport Gas Plant.


Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The Bridgeport Gas Plant resolves findings from PHAs and audits, some of which result in modifications to the process. The most recent PHA was on July 12, 2012 on the Plant 7 addition. Minor changes to the P&IDs may be made after the date of this RMP.  Any changes affecting the quantities of any regulated substances will result in an update of this RMP.
